title: Association type derived from structures:AssociationType
name: rule-association-type-derived-from-association-type
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType"> <sch:let name="is-association-type" value="exists(@name[ends-with(., 'AssociationType')])"/> <sch:let name="has-association-base-type" value=" exists(xs:complexContent[ exists(xs:*[local-name() = ('extension', 'restriction') and exists(@base[ends-with(., 'AssociationType')])])])"/> <sch:assert test="$is-association-type = $has-association-base-type" >A type MUST have an association type name if and only if it is derived from an association type.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A type MUST have an association type name if and only if it is derived from an association type.

title: Association element type is an association type
name: rule-association-el-type-is-association-type
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element[exists(@name)]"> <sch:assert test="exists(@type[ends-with(., 'AssociationType')]) = exists(@name[ends-with(., 'Association')])" >An element MUST have a name that ends in 'Association' if and only if it has a type that is an association type.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element MUST have a name that ends in 'Association' if and only if it has a type that is an association type.

title: Augmentable type has augmentation point element
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType[ @name[not(ends-with(., 'MetadataType')) and not(ends-with(., 'AugmentationType'))] and empty(@appinfo:externalAdapterTypeIndicator) and xs:complexContent]"> <sch:let name="augmentation-point-qname" value="QName(string(nf:get-target-namespace(.)), replace(./@name, 'Type$', 'AugmentationPoint'))"/> <sch:assert test="xs:complexContent/xs:extension/xs:sequence/xs:element[ @ref[resolve-QName(., ..) = $augmentation-point-qname]]" >An augmentable type MUST contain an element use of its corresponding augmentation point element.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An augmentable type MUST contain an element use of its corresponding augmentation point element.

title: Augmentable type has at most one augmentation point element
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType[ @name[not(ends-with(., 'MetadataType')) and not(ends-with(., 'AugmentationType'))] and empty(@appinfo:externalAdapterTypeIndicator) and xs:complexContent]"> <sch:let name="augmentation-point-qname" value="QName(string(nf:get-target-namespace(.)), replace(./@name, 'Type$', 'AugmentationPoint'))"/> <sch:assert test="count(xs:complexContent/xs:extension/xs:sequence/xs:element[ @ref[resolve-QName(., ..) = $augmentation-point-qname]]) le 1" >An augmentable type MUST contain no more than one element use of its corresponding augmentation point element.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An augmentable type MUST contain no more than one element use of its corresponding augmentation point element.

title: Augmentation point element corresponds to its base type
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element[exists(@name[ matches(., 'AugmentationPoint$')])]"> <sch:let name="element-name" value="@name"/> <sch:assert test="exists( parent::xs:schema/xs:complexType[ @name = replace($element-name, 'AugmentationPoint$', 'Type') and exists(@name[ not(ends-with(., 'MetadataType')) and not(ends-with(., 'AugmentationType'))]) and empty(@appinfo:externalAdapterTypeIndicator) and exists(child::xs:complexContent)])" >A schema document containing an element declaration for an augmentation point element MUST also contain a type definition for its base type, a corresponding augmentable type.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A schema document containing an element declaration for an augmentation point element MUST also contain a type definition for its base type, a corresponding augmentable type.

title: An augmentation point element has no type
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element[exists(@name[ matches(., 'AugmentationPoint$')])]"> <sch:assert test="empty(@type)" >An augmentation point element MUST have no type.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An augmentation point element MUST have no type.

title: An augmentation point element has no substitution group
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element[exists(@name[ matches(., 'AugmentationPoint$')])]"> <sch:assert test="empty(@substitutionGroup)" >An augmentation point element MUST have no substitution group.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An augmentation point element MUST have no substitution group.

title: Augmentation point element is only referenced by its base type
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType//xs:element[exists(@ref[ matches(local-name-from-QName(resolve-QName(., ..)), 'AugmentationPoint$')]) ]"> <sch:assert test="QName(string(nf:get-target-namespace(ancestor::xs:complexType[1])), ancestor::xs:complexType[1]/@name) = QName(string(namespace-uri-from-QName(resolve-QName(@ref, .))), replace(local-name-from-QName(resolve-QName(@ref, .)), 'AugmentationPoint$', 'Type'))" >An augmentation point element MUST only be referenced by its base type.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An augmentation point element MUST only be referenced by its base type.

title: Augmentation point element use is optional
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType//xs:element[exists(@ref[ matches(local-name-from-QName(resolve-QName(., ..)), 'AugmentationPoint$')]) ]"> <sch:assert test="exists(@minOccurs) and xs:integer(@minOccurs) = 0" >An augmentation point element particle MUST have attribute minOccurs equal to 0.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An augmentation point element particle MUST have attribute minOccurs equal to 0.

title: Augmentation point element use is unbounded
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType//xs:element[exists(@ref[ matches(local-name-from-QName(resolve-QName(., ..)), 'AugmentationPoint$')]) ]"> <sch:assert test="exists(@maxOccurs) and string(@maxOccurs) = 'unbounded'" >An augmentation point element particle MUST have attribute maxOccurs set to unbounded.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An augmentation point element particle MUST have attribute maxOccurs set to unbounded.

title: Augmentation point element use must be last element in its base type
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType//xs:element[exists(@ref[ matches(local-name-from-QName(resolve-QName(., ..)), 'AugmentationPoint$')]) ]"> <sch:assert test="empty(following-sibling::*)" >An augmentation point element particle MUST be the last element occurrence in its content model.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An augmentation point element particle MUST be the last element occurrence in its content model.

title: Element within instance of augmentation type modifies base
text: Given:Element $relationship establishes a relationship between $base-value and the value of $relationship.

title: Only an augmentation type name ends in AugmentationType
text: A schema component that has a name that ends in AugmentationType MUST be an augmentation type.

title: Schema component with name ending in AugmentationType is an augmentation type
name: rule-augmentation-type-structure
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:*[ends-with(@name, 'AugmentationType')]"> <sch:assert test="self::xs:complexType/xs:complexContent/xs:*[ (self::xs:extension or self::xs:restriction) and ends-with(@base, 'AugmentationType')]" >An augmentation type definition schema component with {name} ending in 'AugmentationType' MUST be an augmentation type definition that is a complex type definition with complex content that extends or restricts an augmentation type.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An augmentation type definition schema component with {name} ending in 'AugmentationType' MUST be an augmentation type definition that is a complex type definition with complex content that extends or restricts an augmentation type.

title: Type derived from structures:AugmentationType is an augmentation type
name: rule-type-derived-from-augmentation-type
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:*[(self::xs:restriction or self::xs:extension) and ends-with(@base, 'AugmentationType')]"> <sch:assert test="ancestor::xs:complexType[ends-with(@name, 'AugmentationType')]" >A type definition derived from an augmentation type MUST be an augmentation type definition</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A type definition derived from an augmentation type MUST be an augmentation type definition

title: Augmentation element type is an augmentation type
name: rule-augmentation-el-type-is-augmentation-type
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element[exists(@name)]"> <sch:assert test="exists(@type[ends-with(., 'AugmentationType')]) = exists(@name[ends-with(., 'Augmentation')])" >An element declaration MUST have a name that ends in "Augmentation" if and only if it has a type that is an augmentation type.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element declaration MUST have a name that ends in "Augmentation" if and only if it has a type that is an augmentation type.

title: Augmentation elements are not used directly
name: rule-aug-el-not-used
text: Within a reference schema document, a complex type definition MUST NOT have an element use of

title: Metadata type has data about data
text: Within the schema, a metadata type MUST contain elements appropriate for a specific class of data about data.

title: Metadata types are derived from structures:MetadataType
name: rule-metadata-type-derived-from-metadata-type
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType"> <sch:let name="is-metadata-type" value="exists(@name[ends-with(., 'MetadataType')])"/> <sch:let name="has-metadata-base-type" value="exists(xs:complexContent[ exists(xs:*[local-name() = ('extension', 'restriction') and exists(@base[ends-with(., 'MetadataType')])])])"/> <sch:assert test="$is-metadata-type = $has-metadata-base-type" >A type MUST be a metadata type if and only if it is derived from a metadata type.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A type MUST be a metadata type if and only if it is derived from a metadata type.

title: Metadata element declaration type is a metadata type
name: rule-metadata-el-type-is-metadata-type
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element[exists(@name)]"> <sch:assert test="exists(@type[ends-with(., 'MetadataType')]) = exists(@name[ends-with(., 'Metadata')])" >An element MUST have a name that ends in 'Metadata' if and only if it has a type that is a metadata type.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element MUST have a name that ends in 'Metadata' if and only if it has a type that is a metadata type.

title: Metadata element has applicable elements
name: rule-metadata-applicable-elements
text: The set of applicable elements for a metadata element declaration are as follows:

title: Name of element that ends in Representation is abstract
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element[@name[ends-with(., 'Representation')]]"> <sch:report role="warning" test="empty(@abstract) or xs:boolean(@abstract) = false()" >An element declaration with a name that ends in 'Representation' SHOULD have the {abstract} property with a value of "true".</sch:report> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element declaration with a name that ends in 'Representation' SHOULD have the {abstract} property with a value of "true".

sectionName: 10. Rules for NIEM modeling, by NIEM concept
title: A substitution for a representation element declaration is a value for a type
text: Any element declaration that is substitutable for a representation element declaration represents an optional representation of a value of a type that carries the representation element.

title: Schema component name composed of English words
text: The name of any XML Schema component defined by the schema SHOULD be composed of words from the English language, using the prevalent U.S. spelling, as provided by [OED].

title: Schema component name has xml:lang
name: rule-component-name-has-xml-lang
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:*[exists(@name)]"> <sch:let name="xml-lang-attribute" value="ancestor-or-self::*[exists(@xml:lang)][1]/@xml:lang"/> <sch:assert test="exists($xml-lang-attribute) and string-length(normalize-space($xml-lang-attribute)) gt 0" >The name of an XML Schema component defined by the schema MUST be in the scope of an occurrence of attribute xml:lang that has a value that is not empty.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The name of an XML Schema component defined by the schema MUST be in the scope of an occurrence of attribute xml:lang that has a value that is not empty.

title: Schema component names have only specific characters
name: rule-names-have-specific-characters
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:*[exists(@name)]"> <sch:assert test="matches(@name, '^[A-Za-z0-9\-_\.]*$')" >The name of an XML Schema component defined by the schema must be composed of only the characters uppercase 'A' through 'Z', lowercase 'a' through 'z', numbers '0' through '9', underscore, hyphen, and period.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The name of an XML Schema component defined by the schema must be composed of only the characters uppercase 'A' through 'Z', lowercase 'a' through 'z', numbers '0' through '9', underscore, hyphen, and period.

title: Punctuation in component name is a separator
text: The characters hyphen (-), underscore (_) MAY appear in a component name only when used as a separator between parts of a word, phrase, or value, which would otherwise be incomprehensible without the use of a separator. The period character (.) MAY appear in component names only when appearing as a separator (as above) or as a decimal within a numeric value. A punctuation character MUST NOT be used as a substitute for camel case in component names, or as a method to avoid camel case in component names.

title: Names use camel case
text: The name of any XML Schema component defined by the schema MUST use the camel case formatting convention.

title: Attribute name begins with lower case letter
name: rule-attribute-names-start-lower-case
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:attribute[exists(@name)]"> <sch:assert test="matches(@name, '^[a-z]')" >Within the schema, any attribute declaration MUST have a name that begins with a lowercase letter ('a'-'z').</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: Within the schema, any attribute declaration MUST have a name that begins with a lowercase letter ('a'-'z').

title: Name of schema component other than attribute and proxy type begins with upper case letter
name: rule-names-start-upper-case
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:attribute"> <sch:report test="false()" role="warning">This rule does not apply to an attribute.</sch:report> </sch:rule> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType[some $name in @name, $extension in xs:simpleContent/xs:extension, $base-qname in resolve-QName($extension/@base, $extension) satisfies $base-qname = QName('http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema', $name)]"> <sch:report test="false()" role="warning">This rule does not apply to a proxy types.</sch:report> </sch:rule> <sch:rule context="xs:*[exists(@name)]"> <sch:assert test="matches(@name, '^[A-Z]')" >Within the schema, an XML Schema component that is not an attribute declaration or proxy type MUST have a name that begins with an upper-case letter ('A'-'Z').</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: This rule does not apply to an attribute.

title: Names use common abbreviations
text: The schema SHOULD use, in defined names, the abbreviations identified by Table 10-1, Abbreviations used in schema component names, rather than their full meanings.

sectionName: 10.8.2.1. Use of Acronyms, Initialisms, Abbreviations, and Jargon
title: Local term declaration is local to its schema document
name: rule-lt-single-doc
text: An element appinfo:LocalTerm MUST establish the meaning of a local term only within the XML Schema document in which it occurs. There MUST NOT be any transitive inheritance of local terminology within schema documents that import the containing schema document.

sectionName: 10.8.2.1. Use of Acronyms, Initialisms, Abbreviations, and Jargon
title: Local terminology interpretation
name: rule-lt-meaning
text: An element information item appinfo:LocalTerm MUST establish a term as follows:

title: Singular form is preferred in name
text: A noun used as a term in the name of an XML Schema component MUST be in singular form unless the concept itself is plural.

title: Present tense is preferred in name
text: A verb used as a term in the name of an XML Schema component MUST be used in the present tense unless the concept itself is past tense.

title: Name does not have nonessential words
text: Articles, conjunctions, and prepositions MUST NOT be used in NIEM component names except where they are required for clarity or by standard convention.

title: Element or attribute name follows pattern
text: Except as specified elsewhere in this document, any element or attribute defined within the schema SHOULD have a name that takes the form:

title: Object-class term identifies concrete category
text: The object-class term of a NIEM component MUST consist of a term identifying a category of concrete concepts or entities.

title: Property term describes characteristic or subpart
text: A property term MUST describe or represent a characteristic or subpart of an entity or concept.

title: Name may have multiple qualifier terms
text: Multiple qualifier terms MAY be used within a component name as necessary to ensure clarity and uniqueness within its namespace and usage context.

title: Name has minimum necessary number of qualifier terms
text: The number of qualifier terms SHOULD be limited to the absolute minimum required to make the component name unique and understandable.

title: Order of qualifiers is not significant
text: The order of qualifiers MUST NOT be used to differentiate names.

title: Redundant term in name is omitted
text: If any word in the representation term is redundant with any word in the property term, one occurrence SHOULD be deleted.

title: Element with simple content has representation term
name: rule-csc-has-rep-term
text: Within the schema, the name of an element declaration that is of simple content SHOULD use an appropriate representation term as found in Table 10-2, Property representation terms.

title: Element with complex content has representation term when appropriate
text: Within the schema, the name of an element declaration that is of complex content, and that corresponds to a concept listed in Table 10-2, Property representation terms, SHOULD use a representation term from that table.

title: Element with complex content has representation term only when appropriate
text: Within the schema, the name of an element declaration that is of complex content and that does not correspond to a concept listed in Table 10-2, Property representation terms SHOULD NOT use a representation term.

title: Machine-readable annotations are valid
text: Every element information item or attribute information item that appears as a machine-readable annotation in a schema MUST be a valid instance, according to its specification.

title: Component marked as deprecated is deprecated component
text: A schema component that has an attribute appinfo:deprecated with a value of true MUST be a deprecated component.

title: Deprecated annotates schema component
name: rule-use-of-deprecated
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[exists(@appinfo:deprecated)]"> <sch:assert test="namespace-uri-from-QName(node-name(.)) = xs:anyURI('http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema')" >The attribute appinfo:deprecated MUST be owned by an element with a namespace name http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The attribute appinfo:deprecated MUST be owned by an element with a namespace name http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema.

title: External import indicator annotates import
name: rule-owner-of-appinfo-conformantindicator
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[exists(@appinfo:externalImportIndicator)]"> <sch:assert test="exists(self::xs:import)" >The attribute {http://release.niem.gov/niem/appinfo/5.0/}externalImportIndicator MUST be owned by an element xs:import.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The attribute {http://release.niem.gov/niem/appinfo/5.0/}externalImportIndicator MUST be owned by an element xs:import.

title: External adapter type indicator annotates complex type
name: rule-owner-of-appinfo-externaladaptertypeindicator
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[exists(@appinfo:externalAdapterTypeIndicator)]"> <sch:assert test="exists(self::xs:complexType)" >The attribute appinfo:externalAdapterTypeIndicator MUST be owned by an element xs:complexType.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The attribute appinfo:externalAdapterTypeIndicator MUST be owned by an element xs:complexType.

title: appinfo:appliesToTypes annotates metadata element
name: rule-owner-of-appinfo-appliestotypes
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[exists(@appinfo:appliesToTypes)]"> <sch:assert test="exists(self::xs:element[exists(@name) and ends-with(@name, 'Metadata')])" >The attribute appinfo:appliesToTypes MUST be owned by a metadata element.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The attribute appinfo:appliesToTypes MUST be owned by a metadata element.

title: appinfo:appliesToTypes references types
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[exists(@appinfo:appliesToTypes)]"> <sch:assert test="every $item in tokenize(normalize-space(@appinfo:appliesToTypes), ' ') satisfies exists(nf:resolve-type(., resolve-QName($item, .)))" >Every item in @appinfo:appliesToTypes MUST resolve to a type.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: Every item in @appinfo:appliesToTypes MUST resolve to a type.

title: appinfo:appliesToElements annotates metadata element
name: rule-owner-of-appinfo-appliestoelements
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[exists(@appinfo:appliesToElements)]"> <sch:assert test="exists(self::xs:element[ exists(@name) and ends-with(@name, 'Metadata')])" >The attribute appinfo:appliesToElements MUST be owned by a metadata element.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The attribute appinfo:appliesToElements MUST be owned by a metadata element.

title: appinfo:appliesToElements references elements
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[exists(@appinfo:appliesToElements)]"> <sch:assert test="every $item in tokenize(normalize-space(@appinfo:appliesToElements), ' ') satisfies count(nf:resolve-element(., resolve-QName($item, .))) = 1" >Every item in @appinfo:appliesToElements MUST resolve to an element.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: Every item in @appinfo:appliesToElements MUST resolve to an element.

title: appinfo:LocalTerm annotates schema
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="appinfo:LocalTerm"> <sch:assert test="parent::xs:appinfo[parent::xs:annotation[parent::xs:schema]]" >The element appinfo:LocalTerm MUST be application information on an element xs:schema.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The element appinfo:LocalTerm MUST be application information on an element xs:schema.

title: appinfo:LocalTerm has literal or definition
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="appinfo:LocalTerm"> <sch:assert test="exists(@literal) or exists(@definition)" >The element {http://release.niem.gov/niem/appinfo/5.0/}LocalTerm MUST have a literal or definition.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The element {http://release.niem.gov/niem/appinfo/5.0/}LocalTerm MUST have a literal or definition.

title: Use structures consistent with specification
text: Any schema or instance MUST use the NIEM structures namespace consistent with the schema as it is defined in Appendix B, Structures namespace, below.

title: Name of type ends in Type
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType[some $name in @name, $extension in xs:simpleContent/xs:extension, $base-qname in resolve-QName($extension/@base, $extension) satisfies $base-qname = QName('http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema', $name)]"> <sch:report test="false()" role="warning">The name of a proxy type does not end in "Type".</sch:report> </sch:rule> <sch:rule context="xs:*[(self::xs:simpleType or self::xs:complexType) and exists(@name)]"> <sch:assert test="ends-with(@name, 'Type')" >A type definition schema component that does not define a proxy type MUST have a name that ends in "Type".</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The name of a proxy type does not end in "Type".

title: Only types have name ending in Type or SimpleType
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:*[exists(@name) and ends-with(@name, 'SimpleType')]"> <sch:assert test="local-name() = 'simpleType'" >A schema component with a name that ends in 'SimpleType' MUST be a simple type definition.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> <sch:rule context="xs:*[exists(@name) and ends-with(@name, 'Type')]"> <sch:assert test="local-name() = 'complexType'" >A schema component with a name that ends in 'Type' and does not end in 'SimpleType' MUST be a complex type definition.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A schema component with a name that ends in 'SimpleType' MUST be a simple type definition.

title: Base type definition defined by conformant schema
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:*[exists(@base)]"> <sch:assert test="some $base-namespace in namespace-uri-from-QName(resolve-QName(@base, .)) satisfies ( $base-namespace = (nf:get-target-namespace(.), xs:anyURI('http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema')) or exists(ancestor::xs:schema[1]/xs:import[exists(@namespace) and $base-namespace = xs:anyURI(@namespace) and empty(@appinfo:externalImportIndicator)]))" >The {base type definition} of a type definition MUST have the target namespace or the XML Schema namespace or a namespace that is imported as conformant.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The {base type definition} of a type definition MUST have the target namespace or the XML Schema namespace or a namespace that is imported as conformant.

title: Name of simple type ends in SimpleType
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:simpleType[@name]"> <sch:assert test="ends-with(@name, 'SimpleType')" >A simple type definition schema component MUST have a name that ends in "SimpleType".</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A simple type definition schema component MUST have a name that ends in "SimpleType".

title: Use lists only when data is uniform
text: Within the schema, a simple type definition that uses xs:list SHOULD NOT be defined if any member of the list requires a property or metadata that is different than other members of the list. All members of the list SHOULD have the same metadata, and should be related via the same properties.

title: List item type defined by conformant schemas
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:list[exists(@itemType)]"> <sch:let name="namespace" value="namespace-uri-from-QName(resolve-QName(@itemType, .))"/> <sch:assert test="$namespace = (nf:get-target-namespace(.), xs:anyURI('http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema')) or exists(ancestor::xs:schema[1]/xs:import[exists(@namespace) and $namespace = xs:anyURI(@namespace) and empty(@appinfo:externalImportIndicator)])" >The item type of a list simple type definition MUST have a target namespace equal to the target namespace of the XML Schema document within which it is defined, or a namespace that is imported as conformant by the schema document within which it is defined.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The item type of a list simple type definition MUST have a target namespace equal to the target namespace of the XML Schema document within which it is defined, or a namespace that is imported as conformant by the schema document within which it is defined.

title: Union member types defined by conformant schemas
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:union[exists(@memberTypes)]"> <sch:assert test="every $qname in tokenize(normalize-space(@memberTypes), ' '), $namespace in namespace-uri-from-QName(resolve-QName($qname, .)) satisfies ($namespace = nf:get-target-namespace(.) or exists(ancestor::xs:schema[1]/xs:import[exists(@namespace) and $namespace = xs:anyURI(@namespace) and empty(@appinfo:externalImportIndicator)]))" >Every member type of a union simple type definition MUST have a target namespace that is equal to either the target namespace of the XML Schema document within which it is defined or a namespace that is imported as conformant by the schema document within which it is defined.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: Every member type of a union simple type definition MUST have a target namespace that is equal to either the target namespace of the XML Schema document within which it is defined or a namespace that is imported as conformant by the schema document within which it is defined.

title: Name of a code simple type ends in CodeSimpleType
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:simpleType[exists(@name) and (xs:restriction/xs:enumeration or xs:restriction[ends-with(local-name-from-QName(resolve-QName(@base, .)), 'CodeSimpleType')])]"> <sch:report test="not(ends-with(@name, 'CodeSimpleType'))" role="warning" >A simple type definition schema component that has an enumeration facet or that is derived from a code simple type SHOULD have a name that ends in "CodeSimpleType".</sch:report> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A simple type definition schema component that has an enumeration facet or that is derived from a code simple type SHOULD have a name that ends in "CodeSimpleType".

title: Code simple type corresponds to a code list
text: A simple type SHOULD have a name ending in CodeSimpleType if and only if it has a correspondence to a list of distinct conceptual entities.

title: Attribute of code simple type has code representation term
name: rule-attribute-of-code-simple-type-has-code-rep-term

title: Element or attribute declaration introduced only once into a type
name: rule-decl-introduced-once
text: Within the schema, an element declaration or attribute declaration MUST NOT be introduced more than once into a type definition. This applies to content acquired by a type by any means, including from a base type definition, via element substitution groups, or through the use of attribute groups.

title: Data definition does not introduce ambiguity
text: Words or synonyms for the words within a data definition MUST NOT be reused as terms in the corresponding component name if those words dilute the semantics and understanding of, or impart ambiguity to, the entity or concept that the component represents.

title: Object class has only one meaning
text: An object class MUST have one and only one associated semantic meaning (i.e., a single word sense) as described in the definition of the component that represents that object class.

title: Data definition of a part does not redefine the whole
text: An object class MUST NOT be redefined within the definitions of the components that represent properties or subparts of that entity or class.

title: Do not leak representation into data definition
text: A data definition SHOULD NOT contain explicit representational or data typing information such as number of characters, classes of characters, range of mathematical values, etc., unless the very nature of the component can be described only by such information.

title: Data definition follows 11179-4 requirements
text: Each data definition MUST conform to the requirements for data definitions provided by [ISO 11179-4] Section 5.2, Requirements.

title: Data definition follows 11179-4 recommendations
text: Each data definition SHOULD conform to the recommendations for data definitions provided by [ISO 11179-4] Section 5.3, Recommendations.

title: Same namespace means same components

title: Consistently marked namespace imports
name: rule-import-is-consistent
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:import"> <sch:let name="namespace" value="@namespace"/> <sch:let name="is-conformant" value="empty(@appinfo:externalImportIndicator)"/> <sch:let name="first" value="exactly-one(parent::xs:schema/xs:import[@namespace = $namespace][1])"/> <sch:assert test=". is $first or $is-conformant = empty($first/@appinfo:externalImportIndicator)" >All xs:import elements that have the same namespace MUST have the same conformance marking via appinfo:externalImportIndicator.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: All xs:import elements that have the same namespace MUST have the same conformance marking via appinfo:externalImportIndicator.

title: Instance must be schema-valid
text: The XML document MUST be schema-valid, as assessed against a conformant schema document set, composed of authoritative, comprehensive schema documents for the relevant namespaces.

title: Empty content has no meaning
text: Within the instance, the meaning of an element with no content is that additional properties are not asserted. There MUST NOT be additional meaning interpreted for an element with no content.

title: Element has only one resource identifying attribute
name: rule-only-one-id
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[exists(@structures:id) or exists(@structures:ref) or exists(@structures:uri)]"> <sch:assert test="count(@structures:id | @structures:ref | @structures:uri) le 1" >An element MUST NOT have more than one attribute that is structures:id, structures:ref, or structures:uri.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element MUST NOT have more than one attribute that is structures:id, structures:ref, or structures:uri.

title: Attribute structures:ref must reference structures:id
name: rule-ref-refs-id
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[@structures:ref]"> <sch:let name="ref" value="@structures:ref"/> <sch:assert test="exists(//*[@structures:id = $ref])" >The value of an attribute structures:ref MUST match the value of an attribute structures:id of some element in the XML document.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The value of an attribute structures:ref MUST match the value of an attribute structures:id of some element in the XML document.

title: Linked elements have same validation root
name: rule-ref-and-id-have-same-validation-root
text: Given that:Every element that has an attribute structures:ref MUST have a referencing element validation root that is equal to the referenced element validation root.

title: Attribute structures:ref references element of correct type
text: Given that:Every element that has an attribute structures:ref MUST have a referenced element type definition that is validly derived from the referencing element type definition.

sectionName: 12.2.2. Uniform resource identifiers in NIEM data
title: structures:uri denotes resource identifier
name: rule-uri-base
text: The value of an attribute structures:uri is a URI-reference, as defined by [RFC 3986], which denotes a resource identifier on the element holding the attribute, in accordance with evaluation consistent with [RFC 3986] and [XML Base].

sectionName: 12.2.2. Uniform resource identifiers in NIEM data
title: structures:id and structures:ref denote resource identifier
name: rule-id-ref-is-uri
text: The value of an attribute structures:id with a value of $value, or an attribute structures:ref with a value of $value, denotes a resource identifier on the element holding the attribute, as would be denoted by an attribute structures:uri with a value of #$value.

sectionName: 12.2.4. Reference and content elements have same meaning
title: Nested elements and references have the same meaning.
text: There MUST NOT be any difference in meaning between a relationship established via an element declaration instantiated by a nested element, and that element declaration instantiated via reference.

title: Order of properties is expressed via structures:sequenceID
text: Given two properties of object $Object,If $Value1 is less than $Value2, then $Property1 MUST be interpreted as occurring before $Property2 within $Object.If $Value2 is less than $Value1, then $Property2 MUST be interpreted as occurring before $Property1 within $Object.The value of an attribute structures:sequenceID MUST be interpreted as an integer value. Comparisons between their values must be interpreted as comparisons between integers.The relative order of two properties, where either does not have attribute structures:sequenceID is unspecified. The relative order of two properties that have the same value for attribute structures:sequenceID is unspecified.

title: Metadata applies to referring entity
text: Within an element instance, when an object $O links to a metadata object via an attribute structures:metadata, the information in the metadata object MUST be applied to the object $O.

title: Referent of structures:relationshipMetadata annotates relationship
text: Within an element instance, when an object $O1 contains an element $E, with content object $O2 or with a reference to object $O2, and $O2 links to a metadata object via an attribute structures:relationshipMetadata, the information in the metadata object MUST be applied to the relationship $E between $O1 and $O2.

title: Values of structures:metadata refer to values of structures:id
text: Given that each IDREF in the value of an attribute structures:metadata must match the value of an ID attribute on some element in the XML document, that ID attribute MUST be an occurrence of the attribute structures:id.

title: Values of structures:relationshipMetadata refer to values of structures:id
text: Given that each IDREF in the value of an attribute structures:relationshipMetadata must match the value of an ID attribute on some element in the XML document, that ID attribute MUST be an occurrence of the attribute structures:id.

title: structures:metadata and structures:relationshipMetadata refer to metadata elements
text: Each element referenced by an attribute structures:metadata or an attribute structures:relationshipMetadata MUST have [element declaration] that is a metadata element declaration.

title: Attribute structures:metadata references metadata element
name: rule-attr-metadata-refs-metadata
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[exists(@structures:metadata)]"> <sch:assert test="every $metadata-ref in tokenize(normalize-space(@structures:metadata), ' ') satisfies exists(//*[exists(@structures:id[. = $metadata-ref]) and ends-with(local-name(), 'Metadata')])" >Each item in the value of an attribute structures:metadata MUST appear as the value of an attribute structures:id with an owner element that is a metadata element.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: Each item in the value of an attribute structures:metadata MUST appear as the value of an attribute structures:id with an owner element that is a metadata element.

title: Attribute structures:relationshipMetadata references metadata element
name: rule-attr-rel-metadata-refs-metadata
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[exists(@structures:relationshipMetadata)]"> <sch:assert test="every $metadata-ref in tokenize(normalize-space(@structures:relationshipMetadata), ' ') satisfies exists(//*[exists(@structures:id[. = $metadata-ref]) and ends-with(local-name(), 'Metadata')])" >Each item in the value of an attribute structures:relationshipMetadata MUST appear as the value of an attribute structures:id with an owner element that is a metadata element.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: Each item in the value of an attribute structures:relationshipMetadata MUST appear as the value of an attribute structures:id with an owner element that is a metadata element.

title: Metadata is applicable to element
text: Given that an element $SUBJECT-ELEMENT uses a metadata element $METADATA-ELEMENT through a value in either an attribute structures:metadata or an attribute structures:relationshipMetadata, the element $SUBJECT-ELEMENT MUST be an applicable element for $METADATA-ELEMENT.
